awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Ice Supersaturation over the Southern Ocean and Antarctica, and its Role in Climate
awd_abstract_narration:
Ice supersaturation plays a key role in cloud formation and evolution, and it determines the partitioning among ice, liquid and vapor phases. Over the Southern Ocean and Antarctica, the transition between mixed-phase and ice clouds significantly impacts the radiative effects of clouds. Remote regions such as the Antarctica and Southern Ocean historically have been under-sampled by in-situ observations, especially by airborne observations. Even though more attention has been given to the cloud microphysical properties over these regions, the distribution and characteristics of ice supersaturation and its role in the current and future climate have not been fully investigated at the higher latitudes in the Southern Hemisphere. One of the main objectives of this study is to analyze observations from three recent major field campaigns sponsored by NSF and DOE, which provide intensive in-situ, airborne measurements over the Southern Ocean and ground-based observations at McMurdo station in Antarctica.

This project will analyze aircraft-based and ground-based observations over the Southern Ocean and Antarctica, and compare the observations with the Community Earth System Model Version 2 (CESM2) simulations. The focus will be on the observations of ice supersaturation and the relative humidity distribution in mixed-phase and ice clouds, as well as their relationship with cloud micro- and macrophysical properties. Observations will be compared to CESM2 simulations to elucidate model biases. Surface radiation and the precipitation budget at the McMurdo station will be quantified and compared against the CESM2 simulations to improve the fidelity of the representation of Antarctic climate (and climate prediction over Antarctica). Results from our research will be released to the community for improving the understanding of cloud radiative effects and the mass transport of water in the high southern latitudes. Comparisons between the simulations and observations will provide valuable information for improving the next generation CESM model. Two education/outreach projects will be carried out by PI Diao at San Jose State University (SJSU), including a unique undergraduate student research project with hands-on laboratory work on an airborne instrument, and an outreach program that uses social media to broadcast news on polar research to the public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Earth’s polar regions have extensive cloud coverage, which can lead to large impacts on Earth’s radiation budget. Cloud formation and evolution in the polar regions are influenced by complex physical processes across a wide range of spatial scales, that is, from the synoptic scale at thousands of kilometers, to microscale inside clouds at tens and hundreds of meters. Because of the large spatial heterogeneities in cloud properties, it is challenging to accurately represent these clouds in global climate models. This work aims to bridge the gap between high-resolution observations (aircraft, ground, and ship-based) and coarser-resolution climate simulations. A large observational dataset was built from eleven NSF flight campaigns and two DOE/NSF ground-based field campaigns to provide a near global-scale coverage for analyzing ice and mixed-phase clouds. In particular, year-long observations at the McMurdo Station, Antarctica during the DOE/NSF ARM West Antarctic Radiation Experiment (AWARE) field campaign have been examined, aiming to understand the factors controlling cloud properties over the West Antarctic Ice Sheet.

 

The Southern Ocean and Antarctic clouds have been found to have more frequent coexistence of ice crystals and supercooled liquid water compared with other regions such as North America and Pacific Ocean. Scale-aware, definition-aware comparison methods have been developed to assess climate simulations from the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) Community Earth System Model (CESM). The CESM climate model version 2 has shown significant improvements compared with the CESM version 1, especially by allowing more supercooled liquid water to occur at temperatures below -10 degree Celsius. Main biases in the climate model have been identified, including underestimations of ice phase frequencies, ice water path, and ice water content in clouds, and underestimation of aerosol indirect effects on ice clouds. Satellite observations from NASA CALIPSO and CloudSat also showed various types of biases when validated against in-situ aircraft observations, highlighting the importance of providing more accurate field campaign observations in the remote polar regions to understand the physical factors controlling cloud microphysical properties. Due to the technical limitations of spaceborne observations, the complex cloud structure and their thermodynamic/dynamic conditions can be hard to derive solely based on satellite retrievals.

 

Multiple key factors have been found to influence cloud formation and evolution, including thermodynamic conditions (i.e., temperature and relative humidity), dynamic conditions (i.e., vertical velocity), and aerosol indirect effects from larger and smaller aerosols. Biases in cloud fraction and cloud phase in the climate model were found to strongly correlate with biases in relative humidity and water vapor, indicating that more future studies are warranted to improve the model representation of water vapor concentrations and their sub-grid scale variabilities. The underestimation of aerosol indirect effects on ice crystals in the model indicates that the model would predict insufficient amount of perturbations of ice microphysical properties due to perturbations of aerosol loading in the atmosphere, leading to too weak sensitivity of clouds to aerosols especially in the relatively clean conditions over Southern Ocean and Antarctica.

 

The project has supported multiple graduate and undergraduate students in pursuing a career in atmospheric science. Six graduate students were supported by this work (some are partially supported). They are currently enrolled in PhD programs or are conducting postdoctoral research at various universities. Three undergraduate students were supported by this work, all of whom still work in the atmospheric science field. The first student is pursuing a PhD degree, the second student is currently working for a California state air agency, and the third student is working for a start-up company on precipitation enhancement.

 

This project also provided the unique opportunity for multiple graduate and undergraduate students to visit the NCAR Earth Observing Laboratory in 2016 – 2019 as part of a summer research trip. Students had the opportunity to collaborate with NCAR scientists to learn more about airborne facilities, aircraft-base instruments, laboratory experiments, and simulations using the NCAR supercomputer. Several journal articles resulted from this OPP grant support, as well as the support of the NCAR supercomputing resources. PI value-added data products on an airborne hygrometer instrument have been provided by PI Diao’s group. This quality-controlled water vapor product has been used in several journal publications, providing higher quality measurements of water vapor and relative humidity during the National Science Foundation Southern Ocean Clouds, Radiation, Aerosol Transport Experimental Study (SOCRATES) campaign.

 

As for enhancing the broader impacts, PI Diao created a YouTube channel called ClimoNemo. PI Diao’s students have helped with creating videos on general education of clouds, aerosols, polar research, and climate change. The channel link is: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCY1ya3QRLqHdSmBGvWl4DbQ
